lines.text: DR MOOZAR, MDCM, MSC., FRCSC
Taunton Surgical Centre
1300 Keith Ross Drive
Oshawa Ontario, L1J 0C7
Dr. Kevin Chen
520 Ellesmere Rd
Scarborough, ON
M1R OB1
Dear Dr. Kevin Chen: (Original addressed to Dr Thomas Fung)
Re: Penelope (Penny) Peters #312163 May 2, 1975 Age: 50 yr HN: 8864 307 510 CB
Dear Dr. Fung:
Thank you for asking me to assess this 50-year-old woman with an enlarging right adrenal
adenoma for an opinion. She was seen in the surgical clinic today unaccompanied.
The story is somewhat unclear. However, from what I gather, she had some nonspecific
abdominal pain which led to an ultrasound examination in 2020 and a lesion was
identified in the adrenal gland as well as the right kidney. She later underwent a CT scan
followed by an MRI and later another CT scan.
The most recent CT scan shows the lesion to be approximately 3.6 cm x 3.1 cm showing
slight increase in size. The consistency is adrenal adenoma.
On further questioning, she does not endorse any symptoms that would be suggestive of
a functional adenoma. However, she does have some increased hirsutism recently. She
has no palpitations, excessive sweating or headaches.
Her past medical history is remarkable for obesity and malignant hyperthermia. Her only
medication is lorazepam as needed for panic attacks. She has no allergies to medications
and she is a non-smoker.
Physical examination was noncontributory.
We discussed reasons for surgical removal of the adrenal gland namely, functional
adrenal adenomas as well as enlarging lesions over the size of 4 cm. There has been
marginal increase in size.
I have taken the liberty of referring her to one of my endocrinology colleagues for an
opinion with regards to assessment for functional studies of the adrenal gland. Once this
is completed, we can discuss further management when I see her in follow-up.
